text: But God shall wound the head of his enemies, and the hairy scalp of such an one as goeth on still in his trespasses.
text_kjv: But God shall wound the head of his enemies, and the hairy scalp of such an one as goeth on still in his trespasses.
text_niv: Surely God will crush the heads of his enemies,the hairy crowns of those who go on in their sins.
text_esv: But God will strike the heads of his enemies, the hairy crown of him who walks in his guilty ways.
text_nlt: But God will smash the heads of his enemies,crushing the skulls of those who love their guilty ways.
text_msg: What's more, he made heads roll,split the skulls of the enemyAs he marched out of heaven,
text_nasb: Surely God will shatter the head of His enemies, The hairy crown of him who goes on in his guilty deeds.
context: Psalm 68 is a victory song, likely composed to celebrate the Ark of the Covenant being brought to its resting place in Jerusalem. It resonates with themes of God's power and triumph over enemies, His care for the vulnerable, and His establishment of His kingdom. The historical background draws from the exodus narrative, the conquest of Canaan, and David's reign. The phrase 'hairy scalp' is significant. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, a full head of hair was a sign of strength, virility, and even status. To wound or shave the head was a sign of defeat, humiliation, and mourning. Scalping, while practiced in other cultures, wasn't a common military practice of the Israelites. The 'hairy scalp' could therefore symbolize those who proudly flaunt their power and rebellion against God. The 'going on still in his trespasses' emphasizes a deliberate and persistent defiance of God's law. This wasn't an accidental slip-up, but a pattern of behavior. It signifies an unrepentant heart that refuses to acknowledge God's authority. Consider the warlike imagery common to the period; God is depicted as a warrior king crushing his enemies. The Psalmist uses vivid language to convey the severity of God's judgment against those who oppose Him and his people. Understanding the Psalm's context of warfare and royal procession helps to appreciate the forcefulness of the verse and its message.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 68:21 emphasizes God's justice and sovereignty. It affirms that God will ultimately punish those who persistently reject Him and his ways. The 'wounding of the head' signifies a decisive defeat of the enemy's power and authority. Itâ€™s not merely a physical wound, but a complete subjugation. The 'hairy scalp' imagery reinforces the idea that those who arrogantly rely on their own strength and pride will be brought low. The phrase 'goeth on still in his trespasses' highlights the importance of repentance. It's not just about committing a sin, but about the persistent, unrepentant nature of that sin. This verse distinguishes between those who stumble and fall but seek forgiveness, and those who deliberately and continuously choose to disobey God. God's judgment is not arbitrary; it is a response to deliberate rebellion. The verse reflects the Old Testament concept of God as a righteous judge who rewards the righteous and punishes the wicked. This understanding is crucial for a balanced view of God's character, recognizing both His love and His justice. It is important to note that this verse, like many in the Old Testament, points forward to the ultimate judgment found in the New Testament. While the Psalm speaks of immediate consequences, the theological implications extend to the final judgment, where all will be held accountable for their actions.
application: Practically, Psalm 68:21 serves as a warning and a call to repentance. It reminds us that our actions have consequences and that persistent rebellion against God will ultimately lead to judgment. We must examine our own lives and ask ourselves if there are any areas where we are 'going on still in our trespasses.' Are there sins we habitually commit without remorse or a desire for change? Are we clinging to pride and self-sufficiency, refusing to acknowledge God's authority in our lives? This verse challenges us to take sin seriously and to actively seek forgiveness and transformation. It calls us to cultivate a humble and contrite heart, recognizing our dependence on God's grace. It also reminds us that true strength comes not from ourselves, but from God. Relying on our own abilities and wisdom will ultimately lead to failure, while trusting in God will bring victory. In our relationships with others, this verse encourages us to approach conflict with humility and a willingness to forgive. While we must stand up for what is right, we should avoid seeking revenge or harboring bitterness. Instead, we should trust that God will ultimately bring justice and vindication. In a world that often glorifies pride and self-assertion, Psalm 68:21 calls us to embrace humility and submission to God's will. It is a reminder that true strength is found not in ourselves, but in God, and that lasting peace comes from obedience to His word.
prayer: Heavenly Father, Your Word declares that You will wound the head of Your enemies and those who persist in their sin. I confess that there are times when I, too, have been stubborn and rebellious, clinging to my own desires instead of seeking Your will. Forgive me for my pride and my unwillingness to surrender fully to You. Help me to examine my heart and identify any areas where I am 'going on still in my trespasses.' Grant me the humility to repent and the strength to turn away from sin. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may walk in obedience and experience the joy of Your presence. Thank you for Your grace and mercy, which are new every morning. I trust in Your justice and Your love, knowing that You will ultimately make all things right. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.
